{"post_stream":{"posts":[{"id":3524881,"name":"SLAB-Mr.Thomas","username":"SLAB-Mr.Thomas","avatar_template":"/user_avatar/www.chiefdelphi.com/slab-mr.thomas/{size}/182153_2.png","created_at":"2025-02-12T16:48:25.317Z","cooked":"

We upgraded our LL 3 to LL 3G by the camera replacement.

The device overheats with the 2025 firmware as the fan runs at too slow of a speed after initially (first few seconds) running fast.

The 2024 firmware keeps the fan at high-speed and does not overheat.

Has anyone come up with a satisfactory solution?

[Yes, LL has been notified multiple times on multiple media by multiple teams - no response.]

LimeLightVision posted that the issue will be fixed this week with an updated download of its OS image.

We unplugged the control pin from the fan connector to the limelight’s PCB, which resulted the fan spinning at the voltage given to it without any software interference.

","post_number":3,"post_type":1,"posts_count":4,"updated_at":"2025-02-13T20:55:10.943Z","reply_count":1,"reply_to_post_number":null,"quote_count":0,"incoming_link_count":1,"reads":110,"readers_count":109,"score":47.0,"yours":false,"topic_id":491366,"topic_slug":"limelight-3g-the-upgrade-overheats","display_username":"","primary_group_name":null,"flair_name":null,"flair_url":null,"flair_bg_color":null,"flair_color":null,"flair_group_id":null,"badges_granted":[],"version":1,"can_edit":false,"can_delete":false,"can_recover":false,"can_see_hidden_post":true,"can_wiki":false,"read":true,"user_title":null,"bookmarked":false,"actions_summary":[{"id":2,"count":1}],"moderator":false,"admin":false,"staff":false,"user_id":64738,"hidden":false,"trust_level":2,"deleted_at":null,"user_deleted":false,"edit_reason":null,"can_view_edit_history":true,"wiki":false,"post_url":"/t/limelight-3g-the-upgrade-overheats/491366/3","custom_user_title":null,"reactions":[{"id":"point_up","type":"emoji","count":1}],"current_user_reaction":null,"reaction_users_count":1,"current_user_used_main_reaction":false,"can_accept_answer":false,"can_unaccept_answer":false,"accepted_answer":false,"topic_accepted_answer":true},{"id":3526480,"name":"SLAB-Mr.Thomas","username":"SLAB-Mr.Thomas","avatar_template":"/user_avatar/www.chiefdelphi.com/slab-mr.thomas/{size}/182153_2.png","created_at":"2025-02-13T21:34:45.702Z","cooked":"

That’s a good idea when the fix wasn’t going to be readily available. Another team said they did the same thing. I learned yesterday that those tiny inexpensive motors with 3 wires have a tachometer signal as the third wire so I think that more precisely the disconnected tach was reading 0 in the software so the software cranked up the voltage to max trying to get it to the speed setpoint.
